Will be called a schemer or deviser of evil. And the scoffer is repulsive to men. Your strength is limited. And those who stagger to the slaughter, Oh hold them back [from their doom]! Does He not consider it who weighs and examines the hearts and their motives? And does He not know it who guards your life and keeps your soul? And will He not repay [you and] every man according to his works? And the drippings of the honeycomb are sweet to your taste. If you find wisdom, then there will be a future and a reward, And your hope and expectation will not be cut off. Do not destroy his resting place; But the wicked stumble in time of disaster and collapse. And do not let your heart be glad [in self-righteousness] when he stumbles, And turn His anger away from your enemy. Or be envious of the wicked, The lamp of the wicked will be put out. And do not associate with those who are given to change [of allegiance, and are revolutionary], And who knows the punishment that both [the L ord and the king] will bring on the rebellious? To show partiality in judgment is not good. Peoples will curse him, nations will denounce him; And a good blessing will come upon them. Who gives a right and straightforward answer. And get it ready for yourself in the field; And do not deceive with your lips [speak neither lies nor half-truths]. I will pay the man back for his deed.” And by the vineyard of the man lacking understanding and common sense; And nettles were covering its surface, And its stone wall was broken down. I looked and received instruction. A little folding of the hands to rest [and daydream],” And your want like an armed man.
For their minds plot violence,
Through [skillful and godly] wisdom a house [a life, a home, a family] is built,
And by knowledge its rooms are filled
A wise man is strong,
For by wise guidance you can wage your war,
Wisdom is too exalted for a [hardened, arrogant] fool;
He who plans to do evil
The devising of folly is sin,
If you are slack (careless) in the day of distress,
Rescue those who are being taken away to death,
If you [claim ignorance and] say, “See, we did not know this,”
My son, eat honey, because it is good,
Know that [skillful and godly] wisdom is [so very good] for your life and soul;
Do not lie in wait, O wicked man, against the dwelling of the righteous;
For a righteous man falls seven times, and rises again,
Do not rejoice and gloat when your enemy falls,
Or the L ord will see your gloating and be displeased,
Do not get upset because of evildoers,
For there will be no future for the evil man;
My son, fear the L ord and the king;
For their tragedy will rise suddenly,
These also are sayings of the wise:
He who says to the wicked, “You are righteous,”
But to those [honorable judges] who rebuke the wicked, it will go well with them and they will find delight,
He kisses the lips [and wins the hearts of people]
Prepare your work outside Afterward build your house and establish a home.
Do not be a witness against your neighbor without cause,
Do not say, “I will do to him as he has done to me;
I went by the field of the lazy man,
And, behold, it was all overgrown with thorns,
When I saw, I considered it well;
“Yet a little sleep, a little slumber,
Then your poverty will come as a robber,

25.verse_text: These are also the proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied: But the glory of kings is to search out a matter. And there comes out [the pure metal for] a vessel for the silversmith [to shape]. And his throne will be established in righteousness. And do not stand in the place of great men; Than for you to be placed lower in the presence of the prince, Whom your eyes have seen. Otherwise what will you do in the end [when your case is lost and] When your neighbor (opponent) humiliates you? And do not reveal another’s secret, And the rumor about you [and your action in court] will have no end. Is a word spoken at the right time. Is a wise reprover to an ear that listens and learns. So is a faithful messenger to those who send him; For he refreshes the life of his masters. Is a man who boasts falsely of gifts [he does not give]. And a soft and gentle tongue breaks the bone [of resistance]. Otherwise, being filled excessively, you vomit it. Or he will become tired of you and hate you. Is a man who testifies falsely against his neighbor (acquaintance). Is confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble. Is he who [thoughtlessly] sings [joyful] songs to a heavy heart. And if he is thirsty, give him water to drink; And the L ord will reward you. And a backbiting tongue, an angry countenance. Than in a house shared with a quarrelsome (contentious) woman. So is good news from a distant land. Is a righteous man who yields and compromises his integrity before the wicked. Nor is it glorious to seek one’s own glory. Is a man who has no self-control over his spirit [and sets himself up for trouble].
It is the glory of God to conceal a matter,
As the heavens for height and the earth for depth, So the hearts and minds of kings are unsearchable.
Take away the dross from the silver,
Take away the wicked from before the king,
Do not be boastfully ambitious and claim honor in the presence of the king,
For it is better that it be said to you, “Come up here,”
Do not rush out to argue your case [before magistrates or judges];
Argue your case with your neighbor himself [before you go to court];
Or he who hears it will shame you
Like apples of gold in settings of silver
Like an earring of gold and an ornament of fine gold
Like the cold of snow [brought from the mountains] in the time of harvest,
Like clouds and wind without rain
By patience and a calm spirit a ruler may be persuaded,
Have you found [pleasure sweet like] honey? Eat only as much as you need,
Let your foot seldom be in your neighbor’s house,
Like a club and a sword and a piercing arrow
Like a broken tooth or an unsteady foot
Like one who takes off a garment in cold weather, or like [a reactive, useless mixture of] vinegar on soda,
If your enemy is hungry, give him bread to eat;
For in doing so, you will heap coals of fire upon his head,
The north wind brings forth rain;
It is better to live in a corner of the housetop [on the flat roof, exposed to the weather]
Like cold water to a thirsty soul,
Like a muddied fountain and a polluted spring
It is not good to eat much honey,
Like a city that is broken down and without walls [leaving it unprotected]

26.verse_text: Like snow in summer and like rain in harvest, So honor is not fitting for a [shortsighted] fool. So the curse without cause does not come and alight [on the undeserving]. And a rod for the backs of fools [who refuse to learn]. Otherwise you, even you, will be like him. Otherwise he will be wise in his own eyes [if he thinks you agree with him]. Cuts off his own feet (sabotages himself) and drinks the violence [it brings on himself as a consequence]. So is a proverb in the mouth of a fool [who cannot learn from its wisdom]. So is he who [absurdly] gives honor to a fool. So is a proverb in the mouth of a fool [who remains unaffected by its wisdom]. So is he who hires a fool or those who [by chance just] pass by. Is a fool who repeats his foolishness. There is more hope for a fool than for him. A lion is in the open square [and if I go outside to work I will be killed]!” So does the lazy person on his bed [never getting out of it]. It wearies him to bring it back to his mouth. Than seven [sensible] men who can give a discreet answer. Is he who, passing by, stops to meddle with a dispute that is none of his business. Firebrands, arrows, and death, And then says, “Was I not joking?” And where there is no whisperer [who gossips], contention quiets down. So is a contentious man to kindle strife. They go down into the innermost chambers of the body [to be remembered and mused upon]. Are burning lips [murmuring manipulative words] and a wicked heart. But he stores up deceit in his heart. For seven abominations are in his heart. His malevolence will be revealed openly before the assembly. And he who rolls a stone [up a hill to do mischief], it will come back on him. And a flattering mouth works ruin.
Like the sparrow in her wandering, like the swallow in her flying,
A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey,
Do not answer [nor pretend to agree with the frivolous comments of] a [closed-minded] fool according to his folly,
Answer [and correct the erroneous concepts of] a fool according to his folly,
He who sends a message by the hand of a fool
Like the legs which are useless to the lame,
Like one who [absurdly] binds a stone in a sling [making it impossible to throw],
Like a thorn that goes [without being felt] into the hand of a drunken man,
Like a [careless] archer who [shoots arrows wildly and] wounds everyone,
Like a dog that returns to his vomit
Do you see a man [who is unteachable and] wise in his own eyes and full of self-conceit?
The lazy person [who is self-indulgent and relies on lame excuses] says, “There is a lion in the road!
As the door turns on its hinges,
The lazy person buries his hand in the dish [losing opportunity after opportunity];
The lazy person is wiser in his own eyes
Like one who grabs a dog by the ears [and is likely to be bitten]
Like a madman who throws
So is the man who deceives his neighbor (acquaintance, friend)
For lack of wood the fire goes out,
Like charcoal to hot embers and wood to fire,
The words of a whisperer (gossip) are like dainty morsels [to be greedily eaten];
Like a [common] clay vessel covered with the silver dross [making it appear silver when it has no real value]
He who hates, disguises it with his lips,
When he speaks graciously and kindly [to conceal his malice], do not trust him,
Though his hatred covers itself with guile and deceit,
Whoever digs a pit [for another man’s feet] will fall into it,
A lying tongue hates those it wounds and crushes,

27.verse_text: Do not boast about tomorrow, For you do not know what a day may bring. A stranger, and not your own lips. But a fool’s [unreasonable] wrath is heavier and more burdensome than both of them. But who is able to endure and stand before [the sin of] jealousy? Than love that is hidden. But the kisses of an enemy are deceitful [because they serve his hidden agenda]. But to the hungry soul any bitter thing is sweet. So is a man who wanders from his home. So does the sweetness of a friend’s counsel that comes from the heart. And do not go to your brother’s house in the day of your disaster. Better is a neighbor who is near than a brother who is far away. That I may reply to him who reproaches (reprimands, criticizes) me. But the naive [who are easily misled] continue on and are punished [by suffering the consequences of sin]. And hold him in pledge when he is surety for an immoral woman [for it is unlikely the debt will be repaid].” It will be counted as a curse to him [for it will either be annoying or his purpose will be suspect]. And a contentious (quarrelsome) woman are alike; And grasps oil with his right hand. So one man sharpens [and influences] another [through discussion]. And he who faithfully protects and cares for his master will be honored. So the heart of man reflects man. Nor are the eyes of man ever satisfied. And each is tested by the praise given to him [and his response to it, whether humble or proud]. Yet his foolishness will not leave him. And pay attention to your herds; Nor does a crown endure to all generations. And herbs of the mountain are gathered in, And the goats will bring the price of a field. For the food of your household, And for the maintenance of your maids.
Let another praise you, and not your own mouth;
Stone is heavy and the sand weighty,
Wrath is cruel and anger is an overwhelming flood,
Better is an open reprimand [of loving correction]
Faithful are the wounds of a friend [who corrects out of love and concern],
He who is satisfied loathes honey,
Like a bird that wanders from her nest [with its comfort and safety],
Oil and perfume make the heart glad;
Do not abandon your own friend and your father’s friend,
My son, be wise, and make my heart glad,
A prudent man sees evil and hides himself and avoids it,
[The judge tells the creditor,] “Take the garment of one who is surety (guarantees a loan) for a stranger;
He who blesses his neighbor with a loud voice early in the morning,
A constant dripping on a day of steady rain
Whoever attempts to restrain her [criticism] might as well try to stop the wind,
As iron sharpens iron,
He who tends the fig tree will eat its fruit,
As in water face reflects face,
Sheol (the place of the dead) and Abaddon (the underworld) are never satisfied;
The refining pot is for silver and the furnace for gold [to separate the impurities of the metal],
Even though you pound a [hardened, arrogant] fool [who rejects wisdom] in a mortar with a pestle like grain,
Be diligent to know the condition of your flocks,
For riches are not forever,
When the grass is gone, the new growth is seen,
The lambs will supply wool for your clothing,
And there will be enough goats’ milk for your food,

28.verse_text: The wicked flee when no one pursues them, But the righteous are as bold as a lion. But when the ruler is a man of understanding and knowledge, its stability endures. Is like a sweeping rain which leaves no food. But those who keep the law [of God and man] struggle with them. But they who long for and seek the L ord understand it fully. Than he who is crooked and two-faced though he is rich. But he who is a companion of gluttons humiliates his father [and himself]. Gathers it for him who is gracious to the poor. Even his prayer is repulsive [to God]. Will himself fall into his own pit, But the blameless will inherit good. But the poor man who has understanding [because he relies on God] is able to see through him. But when the wicked rise [to prominence], men hide themselves. But he who hardens his heart [and is determined to sin] will fall into disaster. Is a wicked ruler over a poor people. But he who hates unjust gain will [be blessed and] prolong his days. Will be a fugitive until death; let no one support him or give him refuge. But he who is crooked (perverse) will suddenly fall. But he who follows worthless people and frivolous pursuits will have plenty of poverty. But he who hurries to be rich will not go unpunished. Because for a piece of bread a man will transgress. And does not know that poverty will come upon him. Than he who flatters with the tongue. And says, “This is no sin,” Is [not only a thief but also] the companion of a man who destroys. But he who trusts in the L ord will be blessed and prosper. But he who walks in [skillful and godly] wisdom will be rescued. But he who shuts his eyes [from their need] will have many curses. But when the wicked perish, the [consistently] righteous increase and become great.
When a land does wrong, it has many princes,
A poor man who oppresses and exploits the lowly
Those who set aside the law [of God and man] praise the wicked,
Evil men do not understand justice,
Better is the poor who walks in his integrity
He who keeps the law [of God and man] is a wise and discerning son,
He who increases his wealth by interest and usury (excessive interest)
He who turns his ear away from listening to the law [of God and man],
He who leads the upright astray on an evil path
The rich man [who is conceited and relies on his wealth instead of God] is wise in his own eyes,
When the righteous triumph, there is great glory and celebration;
He who conceals his transgressions will not prosper, But whoever confesses and turns away from his sins will find compassion and mercy.
Blessed and favored by God is the man who fears [sin and its consequence] at all times,
Like a roaring lion and a charging bear
A leader who is a great oppressor lacks understanding and common sense [and his wickedness shortens his days],
A man who is burdened with the guilt of human blood (murder)
He who walks blamelessly and uprightly will be kept safe,
He who cultivates his land will have plenty of bread,
A faithful (right-minded) man will abound with blessings,
To have regard for one person over another and to show favoritism is not good,
He who has an evil and envious eye hurries to be rich
He who [appropriately] reprimands a [wise] man will afterward find more favor
He who robs his father or his mother
An arrogant and greedy man stirs up strife,
He who trusts confidently in his own heart is a [dull, thickheaded] fool,
He who gives to the poor will never want,
When the wicked rise [to power], men hide themselves;

29.verse_text: He who hardens his neck and refuses instruction after being often reproved (corrected, criticized), Will suddenly be broken beyond repair. But when the wicked man rules, the people groan and sigh. But he who associates with prostitutes wastes his wealth. But a man who takes bribes overthrows it. Is spreading a net for his own feet. But the righteous man sings and rejoices [for his plan brings good things to him]. But the wicked man has no interest in such knowledge. But wise men turn away anger [and restore order with their good judgment]. The foolish man [ignores logic and fairness and] only rages or laughs, and there is no peace (rest, agreement). But the upright are concerned for his life. But a wise man [uses self-control and] holds it back. All his officials will become wicked. The L ord gives light to the eyes of both. His throne shall be established forever. But a child who gets his own way brings shame to his mother. But the righteous will see the downfall of the wicked. Yes, he will delight your soul. But happy and blessed is he who keeps the law [of God]. For though he understands, he will not respond [nor pay attention]. Will find him to be a son in the end. And a hot-tempered and undisciplined man commits many transgressions. But he who has a humble spirit will obtain honor. He hears the curse [when swearing an oath to testify], but discloses nothing [and commits perjury by omission]. But whoever trusts in and puts his confidence in the L ord will be exalted and safe. But justice for man comes from the L ord . And he who is upright in the way [of the L ord ] is repulsive to the wicked.
When the righteous are in authority and become great, the people rejoice;
A man who loves [skillful and godly] wisdom makes his father joyful,
The king establishes (stabilizes) the land by justice,
A man who flatters his neighbor [with smooth words intending to do harm]
By his wicked plan an evil man is trapped,
The righteous man cares for the rights of the poor,
Scoffers set a city afire [by stirring up trouble],
If a wise man has a controversy with a foolish and arrogant man,
The bloodthirsty hate the blameless [because of his integrity],
A [shortsighted] fool always loses his temper and displays his anger,
If a ruler pays attention to lies [and encourages corruption],
The poor man and the oppressor have this in common:
If a king faithfully and truthfully judges the poor,
The rod and reproof (godly instruction) give wisdom,
When the wicked are in authority, transgression increases,
Correct your son, and he will give you comfort;
Where there is no vision [no revelation of God and His word], the people are unrestrained;
A servant will not be corrected by words alone;
Do you see a [conceited] man who speaks quickly [offering his opinions or answering without thinking]? There is more hope for a [thickheaded] fool than for him.
He who pampers his slave from childhood
An angry man stirs up strife,
A man’s pride and sense of self-importance will bring him down,
Whoever is partner with a thief hates his own life;
The fear of man brings a snare,
Many seek the ruler’s favor,
An unjust man is repulsive to the righteous,

30.verse_text: The words of Agur the son of Jakeh, the oracle: T he man says to Ithiel, to Ithiel and to Ucal: And I do not have the understanding of a man [for I do not know what I do not know]. Nor do I have knowledge of the Holy One [who is the source of wisdom]. Who has gathered the wind in His fists? Who has bound the waters in His garment? Who has established all the ends of the earth? What is His name, and what is His Son’s name? Certainly you know! He is a shield to those who trust and take refuge in Him. Or He will reprove you, and you will be found a liar. Do not deny them to me before I die: Give me neither poverty nor riches; Feed me with the food that is my portion, Or that I will not be poor and steal, And so profane the name of my God. Or he will curse you [for your interference], and you will be found guilty. And does not bless its mother. Yet is not washed from its filthiness. And their eyelids are raised in arrogance. And whose jaw teeth are like knives, To devour the afflicted from the earth And the needy from among men. “Give, give!” There are three things that are never satisfied, Four that do not say, “It is enough”: Earth that is never satisfied with water, And fire that never says, “It is enough.” And scorns a mother, The ravens of the valley will pick it out, And the young vultures will devour it. Four which I do not understand: The way of a serpent on a rock, The way of a ship in the middle of the sea, And the way of a man with a maid. She eats and wipes her mouth And says, “I have done no wrong.” And under four it cannot bear up: Under a [spiritually blind] fool when he is filled with food, And under a maidservant when she supplants her mistress. But they are exceedingly wise: Yet they prepare their food in the summer; Yet they make their houses in the rocks; Yet all of them go out in groups; Yet it is in kings’ palaces. Even four which are stately in their stride: And does not turn back before any; And the king when his army is with him. Or if you have plotted evil, put your hand on your mouth. And wringing the nose produces blood; So the churning of anger produces strife.
Surely I am more brutish and stupid than any man,
I have not learned [skillful and godly] wisdom,
Who has ascended into heaven and descended?
Every word of God is tested and refined [like silver];
Do not add to His words,
Two things I have asked of You;
Keep deception and lies far from me;
So that I will not be full and deny You and say, “Who is the L ord ?”
Do not slander or malign a servant before his master [stay out of another’s personal life],
There is a generation (class of people) that curses its father
There is a generation (class of people) that is pure in its own eyes,
There is a generation (class of people)—oh, how lofty are their eyes!
There is a generation (class of people) whose teeth are like swords
The leech has two daughters,
Sheol, and the barren womb,
The eye that mocks a father
There are three things which are too astounding and unexpectedly wonderful for me,
The way of an eagle in the air,
This is the way of an adulterous woman:
Under three things the earth is disquieted and quakes,
Under a servant when he reigns,
Under an unloved woman when she gets married,
There are four things that are small on the earth,
The ants are not a strong people,
The shephanim are not a mighty folk,
The locusts have no king,
You may grasp the lizard with your hands,
There are three things which are stately in step,
The lion, which is mighty among beasts
The strutting rooster, the male goat also,
If you have foolishly exalted yourself,
Surely the churning of milk produces butter,

31.verse_text: The words of King Lemuel, the oracle, which his mother taught him: And what, O son of my womb? And what [shall I advise you], O son of my vows? Nor your ways to that which destroys kings. It is not for kings to drink wine, Or for rulers to desire strong drink, And pervert the rights and justice of all the afflicted. And wine to him whose life is bitter. And no longer remember his trouble. For the rights of all who are unfortunate and defenseless; And administer justice for the afflicted and needy. Her value is more precious than jewels and her worth is far above rubies or pearls. And he will have no lack of gain. All the days of her life. And works with willing hands in delight. She brings her [household’s] food from far away. And gives food to her household And assigns tasks to her maids. With her profits she plants fruitful vines in her vineyard. And makes her arms strong. Her lamp does not go out, but it burns continually through the night [she is prepared for whatever lies ahead]. And her hands hold the spindle [as she spins wool into thread for clothing]. And she reaches out her filled hands to the needy. For all in her household are clothed in [expensive] scarlet [wool]. Her clothing is linen, pure and fine, and purple [wool]. When he sits among the elders of the land. And supplies sashes to the merchants. And she smiles at the future [knowing that she and her family are prepared]. And the teaching of kindness is on her tongue [giving counsel and instruction]. And does not eat the bread of idleness. Her husband also, and he praises her, saying, But a woman who fears the L ord [reverently worshiping, obeying, serving, and trusting Him with awe-filled respect], she shall be praised. And let her own works praise her in the gates [of the city].
What, O my son?
Do not give your [generative] strength to women [neither foreign wives in marriages of alliances, nor concubines],
It is not for kings, O Lemuel,
Otherwise they drink and forget the law and its decrees,
Give strong drink [as medicine] to him who is ready to pass away,
Let him drink and forget his poverty
Open your mouth for the mute,
Open your mouth, judge righteously,
An excellent woman [one who is spiritual, capable, intelligent, and virtuous], who is he who can find her?
The heart of her husband trusts in her [with secure confidence],
She comforts, encourages, and does him only good and not evil
She looks for wool and flax
She is like the merchant ships [abounding with treasure];
She rises also while it is still night
She considers a field before she buys or accepts it [expanding her business prudently];
She equips herself with strength [spiritual, mental, and physical fitness for her God-given task]
She sees that her gain is good;
She stretches out her hands to the distaff,
She opens and extends her hand to the poor,
She does not fear the snow for her household,
She makes for herself coverlets, cushions, and rugs of tapestry.
Her husband is known in the [city’s] gates,
She makes [fine] linen garments and sells them;
Strength and dignity are her clothing and her position is strong and secure;
She opens her mouth in [skillful and godly] wisdom,
She looks well to how things go in her household,
Her children rise up and call her blessed (happy, prosperous, to be admired);
“Many daughters have done nobly, and well [with the strength of character that is steadfast in goodness], But you excel them all.”
Charm and grace are deceptive, and [superficial] beauty is vain,
Give her of the product of her hands,
